Award.AwardTitle: Resolving the source of the solar acoustic oscillations: Preparing for the era of the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope
Award.AbstractNarration:
Similar to the ringing of a bell, excitations on one portion of the surface of the Sun can cause sound (acoustic) waves to travel through the interior of the Sun and generate vibrations that can be observed elsewhere on the solar surface. Solar scientists can use these acoustic waves to probe the deep interior of the Sun through a process called helioseismology. At the very small size scales that new ground-based solar telescopes such as the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST) will be able to observe, little is known about the sources of these acoustic waves. This proposal will investigate the detailed properties of these sources by numerically modeling them and using these models to predict what will be seen through telescope observations. The proposed research will support the training of the next generation of solar scientists. The PI and co-PI will jointly mentor two graduate students, with each student gaining critical experience in the theory, modeling and observation of solar phenomena.

This proposal will investigate solar acoustic modes (p-modes) through a combination of theoretical modeling and observation with the Dunn Solar Telescope (DST). Despite the use of p-modes to probe the interior of the Sun through helioseismology, the detailed properties of the sources of solar p-mode excitation are not well known. The proposers will develop detailed numerical simulations to determine the source excitation mechanisms and test their efficiencies. These simulations will be used to generate synthetic spectra, which can be tested to determine their sensitivity to pressure, temperature and velocity fluctuations. Finally, observations with the DST will be used to search for the predicted signatures of these thermodynamic fluctuations in the spectral lines. The work outlined in the proposal will provide important preparatory science necessary to optimize the high spatial and spectral resolution capabilities of the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar acoustic oscillations allow scientists to determine the physical properties of the interior of the Sun based on wave motions observed at the surface (a field called helioseismology).  The techniques are similar to those used in terrestrial seismology to determine the interior structure of the Earth.  On the Earth, earthquakes are the sources of the seismic waves that penetrate most deeply.  On the Sun, acoustic waves are generated by turbulent convective motions in the outer layers.  Solar acoustic wave sources are numerous, have small amplitudes, and have been difficult to untangle from the background convective motions. The efforts pursued over the course of this grant have allowed us to develop techniques that for the first time allowed us to readily identify individual source events and their location and timing on the Sun.  Using insights obtained from the application of machine learning techniques, we have developed a filter that extracts the source signal from the background noise.  The acoustic waves propagate outward from the source sites like ripples on a pond, and we use those to pin point the source locations (Figure 1:  A snapshot of the convective motions (top) in a simulation of the Sun's photosphere indicating sites of acoustic emission as identified by a convolutional neural network (green circles) along with (bottom) a corresponding filtered image showing the outward propagating acoustic waves;  Figure 2:  A time series of the filtered velocity (top), Doppler velocity (middle), and pressure fluctuations (bottom) at the site of a particular acoustic event, showing the evolution of the granulation and the expansion of the excited wave pulse.)  Our work has tested these techniques on data from numerical simulations, and we are now prepared to apply them to upcoming data from the National Science Foundation's Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST).  In combination with that anticipated high spatial- and temporal-resolution data, this work opens up an new avenue in helioseismology.  Just as terrestrial seismologist can use local wave sources (produced by explosions or thumpers rather than earthquakes) to image the local rock structure beneath the ground during oil and gas extraction, using the techniques developed under this grant, helioseismologists will be able to determine the precise time and location of sources on the Sun, and then use that information and the wave field generated to image the local small scale structure of the plasma beneath the solar surface.  This will allow advances in our understanding of the evolution of small-scale magnetic fields that will impact our ability to identify the underlying causes of solar flares and coronal mass ejections. Predicting these high-energy events is critical to expanding human and technological activities further into outer space.
